journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Frictional response of normal and osteoarthritic articular cartilage in human femoral head

article-meta.aff: 1Orthopedic Surgery and Institute for Skeletal Aging, College of Medicine, Hallym University, Chuncheon, Republic of Korea
2School of Mechanical Engineering, Pusan National University, Busan, Republic of Korea
3Department of Urology, Ulsan University Hospital, University of Ulsan College of Medicine, Ulsan, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Seonghun Park, School of Mechanical Engineering and Institute for Skeletal Aging, Pusan National University, 30 Jangjeon-dong, Geumjeong-gu, Busan 609-735, South Korea. Email: paks@pusan.ac.kr

abstract.p: We evaluated the microscale frictional response of human articular cartilage in different osteoarthritis stages using an atomic force microscope. Four human femoral heads (60–80 years old) with different osteoarthritis stages were explanted, and two cylindrical cartilage samples were sectioned from each femoral head. The microscale frictional coefficient µ of human cartilage in phosphate-buffered saline increased with increasing osteoarthritis stages, resulting in µ = 0.119 ± 0.036 for stage 0 (normal cartilage), 0.151 ± 0.039 for stage 1, 0.158 ± 0.041 for stage 2, and 0.409 ± 0.119 for stage 3. Statistically significant differences of µ values for different osteoarthritis stages were detected only between stage 3 and other stages (p < 0.0001). The average surface roughness Rq significantly increased with increasing osteoarthritis stages, ranging from 137 ± 25 nm for stage 0 to 533 ± 196 nm for stage 3. A significant correlation between µ and Rq for different osteoarthritis stages was observed (R2 = 0.981). These results demonstrate a positive correlation between the osteoarthritis stages and cartilage surface roughness, and the dependence of the human cartilage frictional response, on osteoarthritis progression. The results could be due to a decrease in the superficial zone protein concentration during the natural progression of osteoarthritis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Articular cartilage is a bearing material that covers the ends of long bones of diarthrodial joints, thus allowing joints to slide, glide, and rotate smoothly with minimal friction and wear due to the biphasic nature of articular cartilage and the mechanics of interstitial fluid flow.1–3 A low frictional coefficient of the cartilage-on-cartilage bearing is important to minimize cartilage wear and mitigate the irreversible loss of structural and mechanical functions due to aging and pathological conditions such as osteoarthritis (OA).4 The frictional coefficient of cartilage, which has been reported to depend on the loading duration, ranged from 0.005 to 0.04 for the cartilage-on-cartilage bearing1,5,6 and from 0.1 to 0.57 for the cartilage-on-metal bearing.4,7,8

OA is a degenerative disease of diarthrodial joints that causes the articular surface to wear down after a period of time,7,9 and changes in the microscale structure of cartilage extracellular matrix molecular components due to OA greatly affect the mechanical9 and tribological behaviors of articular cartilage.10 As described in the literature, many investigators have studied the relationship between the frictional and mechanical responses of animal cartilage (e.g. bovine, porcine, sheep, canine, and rabbit articular cartilage) and cartilage degradation by simulating OA with either enzymatic treatments11–14 or mechanical abrasion.15–20 It has been reported that the macroscale frictional coefficient increases with increasing cartilage degradation due to the loss of interstitial fluid pressurization and/or the decrease in protein concentration at the cartilage surface. Using macroscale pin-on-disk testing, Bell et al. compared the frictional response between healthy and degenerated bovine cartilage that was induced on the cartilage surface by roughening with standard grade emery paper. They reported that degenerated cartilage produced a higher frictional coefficient than healthy cartilage due to damage to the cartilage surface and collagen structure beneath the surface layer, thereby resulting in depletion of the biphasic lubrication of the cartilage.17 Basalo et al. studied the effect of enzymatic treatment on the frictional response of bovine articular cartilage against glass. They also found that the frictional coefficient significantly increased due to the reduction of proteoglycan content in the cartilage surface after treatment with chondroitinase ABC.13

Several molecules such as superficial zone protein (SZP), hyaluronic acid (HA), and surface-active phospholipid have been reported as the effective boundary lubricants of articular cartilage.7,15,17–20 SZP, which is also known as lubricin and PRG4, is present in the cartilage superficial layer and plays an important role in reducing cartilage friction.18,19 HA is the main component of synovial fluid and primarily responsible for the viscosity of synovial fluid.20 Surface-active phospholipid is also an important constituent of synovial fluid and has been reported to reduce cartilage friction by adsorbing phosphate head groups onto the articular surface.15

The atomic force microscope (AFM) has increasingly been used to investigate the microscale mechanical and frictional responses of biological materials, including articular cartilage.9,21–24 The AFM could accurately reveal cartilage frictional behaviors in the boundary lubrication regime because it can simulate a single asperity contact between the AFM tip and the cartilage surface. Through AFM frictional measurements, SZP molecules or lubricin (PRG4) have been reported to significantly improve cartilage boundary lubrication and have served to reduce cartilage friction and wear.23 AFM frictional measurements on cartilage could preserve the cartilage superficial layer by sliding the AFM tip on the cartilage surface within a load magnitude of several nanonewtons,24 as the presence of SZP in the cartilage superficial layer is a key factor in determining cartilage frictional properties.11,24,25 The small AFM tip diameter also allows cartilage frictional measurements to exclude the confounding effect of cartilage interstitial fluid pressurization and produces the AFM frictional coefficients comparable to a macroscale equilibrium value; the macroscale cartilage frictional coefficient is initially very small and reaches a steady-state equilibrium value due to the time-dependent decrease in cartilage interstitial pressurization, while the microscale AFM frictional coefficient remains constant over time and corresponds to a macroscale equilibrium value due to negligible cartilage interstitial pressurization caused by the small AFM tip diameter, as reported in the literature.22,23,26 However, the relation between friction and wear in living systems is more sophisticated than in machines, and low friction is not necessarily correlated to low wear because of self-repair mechanisms.27 Furthermore, normal and OA cartilage surfaces are structurally different.28,29 Normal cartilage presenting a smooth surface consists of fine collagen fibrils with tangential orientation and elongated chondrocytes aligned parallel to the surface,29 whereas OA cartilage has been observed to soften with fibrillation and erosions at the surface. At microscopic level, there is evidence of degenerative changes in OA cartilage, such as cartilage clefts, loss of the cartilage layers, chondrocyte cell death, and chondrocyte cloning.28 These structural changes in the articular surface during OA progression may lead to changes in the frictional properties of the cartilage. Thus, characterization of the surface roughness and frictional coefficient on the surface layer of both normal and OA cartilage is important for understanding the role of the cartilage superficial layer in the lubrication of diarthrodial joints with OA.

In some studies, investigators have reported the microscale frictional properties of normal bovine cartilage,22 murine cartilage,23 and enzyme-treated bovine cartilage.24 However, the frictional properties of naturally progressed OA cartilage in human hip joints and their relationships to surface properties have not yet been characterized. Therefore, the objective of this study is to experimentally verify the hypothesis that the microscale frictional response and surface properties of human articular cartilage vary with OA stages and are related to each other. In addition, we develop a new methodology based on torsion theory to calculate AFM frictional coefficients.

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p: Human femoral heads with different OA stages were explanted from the total hip replacement operations of four patients (between 60 and 80 years old) at Hallym University Medical Center, South Korea. The samples were frozen at −20 °C for 1 month until thawed for specimen preparation in order to keep their properties close to that of living tissue (Figure 1). The stages of OA were classified for each cartilage sample by an experienced doctor using the Outerbridge classification system,30 which classifies cartilage degeneration into stages with increasing severity of OA as follows: stage 0 (OA0) describes normal cartilage, stage 1 (OA1) refers to damage in the superficial cartilage layer, stage 2 (OA2) represents damaged cartilage down to the tidemark, and stage 3 (OA3) describes damage in all cartilage layers. Using a biopsy punch with an inside diameter of 5 mm, two articular cartilage samples were sectioned from areas on each femoral head with the relevant Outerbridge scores to create cylindrical test samples (diameter = 5 mm, h = 0.5 mm) that were stored in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) solution (P5493; Sigma–Aldrich, St Louis, MO, USA) at a temperature of 4 °C for no more than 24 h before the experiments. Prior to the AFM measurements, each OA cartilage sample was first glued to a cylindrical flat plate (1 mm in thickness and 19 mm in diameter) and then affixed to a 50-mm polystyrene Petri dish with cyanoacrylate adhesive. All OA cartilage samples were kept in PBS at room temperature throughout testing.

caption.p: Representative human femoral heads with different OA stages explanted from total hip replacement operations: (a) OA2 and (b) OA3.

sec.title: AFM measurements
sec.p: AFM frictional and surface roughness measurements were conducted with normal and OA cartilage samples entirely submerged in PBS solution and imaged at room temperature using an AFM device (XE 70; Park Systems Corp., Suwon South Korea). The AFM was placed in a sealed box and equipped with software (version 1.8.0; XEI, Park Systems Corp.) for image processing and the calculation of the applied normal force and surface roughness. Triangular silicon-nitride cantilevers (normal spring constant kN = 0.32 N/m) with 4.5-μm-diameter polystyrene spherical tips (Novascan Technologies, Ames, IA, USA) were used for the AFM measurements. The AFM probe was submerged in PBS for 30 min prior to imaging to allow for thermal equilibration at room temperature. Surface scanning of a 40 × 40-μm area with a resolution of 256 × 256 pixels at a scan frequency of 1 Hz and scanning velocity of 80 μm/s was performed in contact mode. As described in Duong et al.,31 the AFM frictional coefficient µ of normal and OA articular cartilage was calculated from the linear slope of the plot of the frictional forces versus the normal forces. The frictional force FL was calculated from the whole AFM image of a 40 × 40-μm scanned area using the relation FL = VLFM × SL × kL, where VLFM is the lateral voltage signal, SL is the lateral sensitivity, and kL is the lateral spring constant. The lateral voltage signal VLFM was obtained as one-half of the average value of the difference between the forward and backward voltage signals from the scanned images. The lateral sensitivity SL, which is proportional to the normal sensitivity (SN = 78 nm/V), was calculated from SL = (3/2)(h/L)(VLFM/VA−B)SN,32 where h is the tip height, L is the cantilever length, and VLFM and VA−B are the lateral and vertical voltage signals of the scanned image, respectively.

In order to calculate the lateral spring constant kL, the triangular cantilever was subdivided into two parts: a triangular plate (I) and two prismatic beams (II) (Figure 2). The twist angle due to a constant torque T applied to the triangular plate (I) is given by

caption.p: Optical microscope image of a triangular silicon-nitride cantilever with a 4.5-μm-diameter polystyrene spherical tip, and detailed parameters of the cantilever.

sec.p: where J is the polar moment of inertia, G = E/2(1 +ν) is the shear modulus, E is the elastic modulus, and ν is Poisson’s ratio of silicon nitride. For a thin rectangular cross section of width w and thickness t, J is approximated by J = wt3/3.33 For a varying width of w(x) = xtanα+a (Figure 2), using J(x) = w(x)t3/3 and equation (1), the twist angle due to a constant torque T is given by
where α is the half-angle between cantilever legs, and L1 and a are the cantilever dimensions, as shown in Figure 2. Similarly, the twist angle of the beams (II) is given by
Thus, the total twist angle of the triangular cantilever is given by
The torsional spring constant kφ was obtained using kφ = T/φ and equation (4), and the lateral spring constant kL becomes

Using equation (5) and the normal spring constant kN approximated by kN = Ewt3/2L3 for a triangular cantilever,34 the lateral spring constant kL for the triangular silicon-nitride cantilever, which is needed to calculate the frictional force of the scanned area, is related to the normal spring constant kN as follows

The specifications of the triangular silicon-nitride cantilever were determined using an optical microscope with high magnification (Eclipse LV100; Nikon Instruments, Tokyo Japan) and are shown in Table 1. The value calculated for the lateral spring constant is kL = 99.85 N/m.

caption.p: Material property of silicon-nitride and triangular cantilever dimensions measured by optical microscope.

sec.p: The values of the root mean squared surface roughness Rq, the normal force, and the vertical and lateral voltage signals were simultaneously measured over the same scanned area (40 μm × 40 μm) at a scanning velocity of 80 μm/s. The measurements of the frictional forces were repeated to obtain five values of the normal force in the range of 4–12 nN at an increment of 2 nN at each location, generating five values of the frictional and normal forces at one location. The average value of AFM frictional coefficient was computed from 16 different locations (8 different locations for each sample) on the OA cartilage surface.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: A one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to detect statistical differences in the surface roughness and the frictional coefficient between different OA stages. The significance level was set to α = 0.05. Post hoc testing of means was performed using Tukey’s adjustments.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Representative results of surface roughness values for all OA stages are described in Figure 3. The average root mean squared surface roughness values Rq over the same 40 × 40-μm scanned area were Rq = 137 ± 25 nm for OA0 (n = 16), Rq = 233 ± 55 nm for OA1 (n = 16), Rq = 226 ± 55 nm for OA2 (n = 16), and Rq = 533 ± 196 nm for OA3 (n = 16). Representative results of the AFM frictional coefficients µ for all stages of OA are also shown in Figure 4. The frictional coefficients for human articular cartilage in PBS increased with increasing OA stages, resulting in µ = 0.119 ± 0.036 for OA0 (n = 16, R2 = 0.973 ± 0.031), µ = 0.151 ± 0.039 (n = 16, R2 = 0.976 ± 0.040) for OA1, µ = 0.158 ± 0.041 (n = 16, R2 = 0.968 ± 0.036) for OA2, and µ = 0.409 ± 0.119 (n = 16, R2 = 0.976 ± 0.056) for OA3.

caption.p: Representative AFM image topographies over the 40 × 40-μm scanned area, and line profile analysis over a length of 40 μm showing severe wear to the cartilage surfaces with increasing OA stages. AFM image topographies, used to calculate surface roughness Rq of the human articular cartilage surface in PBS solution, were taken with 4.5-μm-diameter polystyrene spherical tips at a scanning velocity of 80 μm/s. (a) OA0, (b) OA1, (c) OA2, and (d) OA3.

Representative plots of frictional forces versus normal forces, with the linear slope yielding the AFM frictional coefficient µ measured for five values of the normal force in the range of 4–12 nN at an increment of 2 nN at each location. (a) OA0, (b) OA1, (c) OA2, and (d) OA3. The ranges of R2 in the linear fits of OA0, OA1, OA2, and OA3 were 0.888–0.996, 0.881–0.996, 0.888–0.998, and 0.776–1.000, respectively, while the average values of R2 were 0.973 for OA0, 0.976 for OA1, 0.968 for OA2, and 0.976 for OA3.

sec.p: Statistically significant differences in µ were detected only between OA3 and other OA stages (i.e. between OA3 and OA2, OA3 and OA1, and OA3 and OA0) (p< 0.0001; Figure 5(a)). Similarly, there were statistically significant differences in Rq between OA3 and other OA stages (p < 0.0001; Figure 5(b)). A significant correlation between µ and Rq for different OA stages was observed (R2 = 0.981), as shown in Figure 6. Nevertheless, within every stage of OA (i.e. within OA0, OA1, OA2, and OA3), no significant correlation between µ and Rq was detected (R2 = 0.044, 0.029, 0.002, and 0.015, respectively).

caption.p: (a) AFM frictional coefficient µ. (b) Surface roughness Rq of human articular cartilage in PBS solution, representing the statistical increases in µ and Rq with increasing OA stages. The mean ± standard deviation values of µ and Rq were measured over an area of 40 μm × 40 μm at a scanning velocity of 80 μm/s and were averaged from measurements at 16 different locations on two cartilage samples of each OA score from a single femoral head.
Plot of AFM frictional coefficient µ versus surface roughness Rq with different OA stages, showing the significant correlation between µ and Rq.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The microscale frictional response of human articular cartilage at different OA stages was measured in PBS solution using a new method developed to calculate microscale AFM frictional coefficients. In previous studies,35,36 the triangular cantilever was approximated to two ideal rectangular beams, and a calculation of strain energy stored in the beams was used to determine the lateral spring constant kL, which was reported to be kL = 101.32 N/m. In our proposed method, the triangular cantilever was subdivided into a triangular plate and two prismatic beams to calculate a more accurate value of kL, which directly affects the frictional coefficient values, by representing the original detailed shape of a triangular cantilever beam without any approximation or idealization. Then, the value kL = 99.85 N/m was determined based on torsion theory. The accuracy of the measurements of frictional coefficients in this study is indicated by the large value of the generalized correlation coefficient R2 for the linear fit between the frictional and normal forces (Figure 4). The values of µ have been reported for the normal surfaces of bovine (µ∼0.15),22 murine (µ∼0.23),23 and porcine cartilage (µ∼0.25)23 in PBS by AFM frictional measurements and summarized in Table 2. Nevertheless, to the best of our knowledge, the frictional responses of naturally progressed OA cartilage in human hip joints are characterized for the first time in this study.

caption.p: Summary of literature findings on the mechanical and tribological properties of articular cartilage and cartilage replacement material by AFM measurements.

tr.td: AFM frictional coefficient is representative of the macroscale equilibrium frictional coefficient.
Cartilage frictional properties may not vary significantly among species.
SZP plays an intrinsic and critical role in boundary lubrication at the articular cartilage surface.
Mice (M) cartilage with ages; human (H) OA cartilage
Nanoscale (Nano) elastic modulus of mice cartilage increases with age while that of human cartilage decreases with OA stages.
The frictional property of the retrieved CoCr femoral head is not significantly correlated with its surface roughness.

sec.p: The primary findings of this study are the significant correlation between OA stages and cartilage surface roughness, and the dependence of the microscale frictional response of human articular cartilage on OA progression. An increase in µ with increasing OA stages (Figure 5(a)) ranging from µ∼0.119 for OA0 to µ∼0.409 for OA3 can be explained by damage to the cartilage surface that occurs during the natural progression of OA. This damaged cartilage surface is clearly shown on the AFM images (Figure 3), leading to a significant increase in cartilage surface roughness Rq with increasing OA stages (Rq∼137 nm for OA0 and Rq∼533 nm for OA3; Figure 5(b)). Damage to the cartilage surface during OA progression is also reported in other studies.11,28,29 Stachowiak et al. studied the frictional properties of rat femur cartilage against a stainless steel plate through a macroscale pin-on-disk device. They reported that damage to the cartilage surface over the loading time produced an increase in µ.37 Increased µ values for damaged articular surfaces have also been reported in macroscale frictional studies performed on bovine cartilage against itself,4 bovine cartilage against metal,17 and sheep cartilage against stainless steel.15

The dependence of the cartilage frictional response on OA progression is also consistent with enzyme treatment studies in which OA cartilage was simulated at both the microscale24 and the macroscale.13,14,16,17 Chan et al. used an AFM to investigate the microscale frictional response of degenerated bovine cartilage after trypsin treatments and found that SZP plays an important role in the boundary lubrication of articular cartilage. A decrease in the SZP concentration at the bovine cartilage surface following trypsin digestion increased the value of µ.24 Similarly, a decrease in the SZP concentration with treatments of secretory phospholipase A2 (sPLA2) led to an increase in the value of µ for porcine mandibular condylar cartilage measured using a pendulum friction tester.14 A reduction in the SZP concentration at the surfaces of sheep38 and human39 cartilage with OA has also been reported. Another important protein whose presence directly contributes to the cartilage frictional response is proteoglycan, and a decrease in proteoglycan content by enzymatic treatments resulted in an increase in the frictional coefficient when compared to normal cartilage.13,40,41 Aging and OA also reduced proteoglycan content by cartilage matrix degeneration and were associated with changes in cartilage mechanical and frictional responses.9,42 Moreover, preserving cartilage surface proteins (e.g. SZP) helps to protect articular cartilage from friction and wear by enhancing boundary lubrication, and the removal of these proteins leads to the pathologic status of cartilage degradation such as OA.43 Therefore, it is possible that the increase in the cartilage frictional coefficient in our study with increasing OA stages may be due to the decreased SZP concentration at the cartilage superficial layer during natural progression of OA. Besides SZP, additional research is needed to elucidate the role of synovial fluid proteins, such as bovine serum albumin (BSA) and γ-globulin, in the boundary lubricating ability of human OA articular cartilage.

The current results of µ for human cartilage increased from 0.12 to 0.41 with increasing OA stages. Similar observations have been reported in the literature: The macroscale frictional coefficient for bovine cartilage against metal has been reported to have increased from 0.10 to 0.57 due to increasing wear over the loading time.4,7,8 Furthermore, the frictional coefficient of normal human cartilage in our study (µ∼0.12) is comparable to that of immature bovine cartilage at the microscale (µ∼0.15) and macroscale (µ∼0.14)22 when considering different ages and species. Another interesting result of the present study is that although µ correlates linearly with Rq between different OA stages (as shown by the near-unity value of the generalized correlation coefficient (R2∼0.981) of the linear fit (Figure 6)), no significant correlation was observed between µ and Rq within each OA stage. These results are presumably caused by the fact that the range of changes in Rq between different OA stages is much greater than that within each OA, thus resulting in a significant correlation between Rq and µ and are consistent with previous microscale frictional studies of normal bovine, porcine, and murine articular cartilage.22,23,31 We believe that the spherical shape of the tip with a relatively large diameter (4.5 μm in diameter) can minimize for the AFM tip to lodge itself into the valley of a cleft on the cartilage surface and prevent the coupling of torsional twist of the cantilever due to surface cracks, as is partially evidenced by the result that no significant correlation between Rq and µ was observed within each OA stage. However, regarding a significant correlation between Rq and µ for different OA stages, a further well-designed study is needed to clearly address whether the frictional coefficient depends on the primary, secondary, or tertiary surface features of articular cartilage. The roughness measured at the normal human cartilage surface was Rq∼137 nm in this study, and the values of other animals were Ra∼95–130 nm for rabbit mandibular condyle cartilage,44Rq∼201 nm for murine cartilage,23Rq∼325 nm for porcine cartilage,23 and Rq∼374–462 nm for bovine cartilage.22,26 These results also suggest that the surface roughness of normal articular cartilage varies with species to a significant degree.

One limitation of this study is the use of polystyrene AFM tips for frictional measurements, which are not representative of physiological contact conditions of cartilage-on-cartilage in human diarthrodial joints. Although the contact of polystyrene material on articular cartilage could not ideally mimic the cartilage-on-cartilage contact, the present study could nevertheless describe the relative differences in the tribological properties (i.e. frictional coefficient and surface roughness) of human cartilage with different OA stages. The potential effect of the hydrodynamic drag force on the frictional measurements have also been estimated because the spherical AFM tip moves back and forth at a speed of 80 μm/s in PBS. The hydrodynamic drag force was predicted by Stokes’ solution for laminar flow around a sphere since the Reynolds number is Re = ρVD/η≈0.36 × 10−3≪1, where ρ = 1000 kg/m3, V = 80 μm/s, D = 4.5 μm, η = 10−3 Pa·s.22 The resulting hydrodynamic drag force, FD = 3πηDV≈ 0.0034 nN, is found to be negligible as compared to the frictional forces calculated from AFM measurements ranging from 0.5 to 5 nN. In the present study, the benefits of the AFM compared to other traditional testing methods are the ability to simultaneously measure local frictional properties and structural surface features (e.g. topography and surface roughness) by preserving the soft tissue surface, thus facilitating earlier detection of the initial changes in OA cartilage.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: We demonstrated a positive correlation between OA stages and cartilage surface roughness, and the dependence of the microscale frictional response of human articular cartilage on OA stages. These results could be due to a decrease in the SZP concentration during the natural progression of OA.

ack.p: Sang-Soo Lee and Cong-Truyen Duong contributed equally to this work.
